coredata.dc:title: Reinforced flexible solid-state electrolyte membrane by polyurethane polymer of intrinsic microporosity for high-energy-density lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Hu, Xiaoyan
Zhang, Baoquan
coredata.dc:description: Poly (ethylene oxide) (PEO)-based solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) are restricted in commercial applications due to the low ionic conductivity at ambient temperature and fragile mechanical properties. Polyurethanes (PUs) are unique materials coupled with superior rigidity and flexibility. Herein, we designed a novel polyurethane polymer of intrinsic microporosity (PPU), which was incorporated with PEO-based polymer electrolyte to prepare composite polymer electrolyte (CPE). The physicochemical and electrochemical properties of CPE membranes were explored. The high ionic conductivity (1.82 × 10−3 S cm−1 at 50 °C) and superior interfacial stability with the lithium anode was obtained. Furthermore, the rate performances and the cycling properties of CPE in LiFePO4 (LFP) batteries were extensively studied. The CPE-15% PPU film showed the excellent electrochemical stability of 84.3% capacity retention after 890 cycles at 0.5 C and 82.4% capacity retention after 500 cycles at 1.0 C at 50 °C. Especially, the CPE matched with high-voltage LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 (NCM523) cathode delivered long-term stable cycling performances. The novel polymer electrolyte acquired could open up a new horizon to achieve high stable lithium metal batteries.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Polyurethane
Polyethylene oxide
Solid-state composite electrolytes
All-solid-state batteries

(a) Schematic illustration for the preparation of the resultant CPE; (b) XRD patterns; (c) Comparative Arrhenius plots of ionic conductivity versus temperature (30–50 °C) (inset: linear fitting of the data for calculation of activation energies); (d) Nyquist plots of CPE-15% PPU at different temperatures. Top-view and cross-sectional SEM images of (e) SPE; (f) CPE-15% PPU; (g) Nitrogen mapping of CPE-15% PPU.
(a) DSC thermograms; (b) Nanoindentation measurement results; (c) Stress−strain curves; (d) LSV curves; (e) Chronoamperometry curves; (f) Nyquist plots before and after polarization.
(a) The lithium-ion transport pathways with schematic mechanism of Li+ transport in SPE and CPE-15% PPU; (b) FTIR spectra for PEO, LiTFSI, SPE and CPE-15% PPU.

(a–c) Galvanostatic cycling of Li symmetric batteries; (d, f) Schematic illustration of the lithium dendrite inhibition; SEM images of the Li electrode surface obtained from (e) Li/SPE/Li; (g) Li/CPE-15% PPU/Li after 50 h.

(a) Rate performance of LFP/Li cells; (b) The charge/discharge curves at various rates; The cycling performance of LFP/Li battery and charge/discharge voltage curves (c, d) at 0.5 C; (e, f) at 1.0 C; (g, h) The cycling performance of NCM523/Li battery using CPE-15% PPU and charge/discharge voltage curves at 0.5 C. Electrochemical performance was tested at 50 °C.

head.ce:title: Reinforced flexible solid-state electrolyte membrane by polyurethane polymer of intrinsic microporosity for high-energy-density lithium metal battery

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, 135 Ya Guan Road, Jinnan District, Tianjin, 300350, China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering
School of Chemical Engineering and Technology

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, 135 Ya Guan Road, Jinnan District, Tianjin, 300350, China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Poly (ethylene oxide) (PEO)-based solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) are restricted in commercial applications due to the low ionic conductivity at ambient temperature and fragile mechanical properties. Polyurethanes (PUs) are unique materials coupled with superior rigidity and flexibility. Herein, we designed a novel polyurethane polymer of intrinsic microporosity (PPU), which was incorporated with PEO-based polymer electrolyte to prepare composite polymer electrolyte (CPE). The physicochemical and electrochemical properties of CPE membranes were explored. The high ionic conductivity (1.82 × 10−3 S cm−1 at 50 °C) and superior interfacial stability with the lithium anode was obtained. Furthermore, the rate performances and the cycling properties of CPE in LiFePO4 (LFP) batteries were extensively studied. The CPE-15% PPU film showed the excellent electrochemical stability of 84.3% capacity retention after 890 cycles at 0.5 C and 82.4% capacity retention after 500 cycles at 1.0 C at 50 °C. Especially, the CPE matched with high-voltage LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 (NCM523) cathode delivered long-term stable cycling performances. The novel polymer electrolyte acquired could open up a new horizon to achieve high stable lithium metal batteries.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: To satisfy the increasing demand of electric vehicles and energy storage systems, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) with high-energy density and reliable safety have attracted more attention in the research field of energy storage devices [1–3]. Usually, conventional LIBs use organic liquid electrolytes, which present challengeable issues such as flammability and side chemical reactions with Li anode. Besides, the uneven electrode-position of Li could cause the uncontrollable Li dendritic. Once the separator is penetrated through, the intense heat release and potential explosion hazard would be emerged [4,5]. Recent studies suggested that solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) could be a promising solution to resolve the above problems [6–8]. Especially, solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) might provide extra attractive advantages.

Compared with inorganic solid electrolytes, SPEs revealed superiorities in aspects of lightweight property, excellent flexibility, and easy-processing [9–11]. However, the main obstacles including low ion conductivity, fragile mechanical strength and insufficient electrochemical stability impeded their industrial applications [12,13]. To overcome such short-comings, several alternative strategies, such as doped with ceramic nanoparticles, liquid plasticizers, cross-linking and blending polymers, have been extensively proposed [14–16]. Among these alternates, the hybrid of nanoparticles or polymers with PEO polymer can effectively increase the mechanical properties of PEO-based SPEs. However, the unavoidable issues of cluster aggregation and phase separation greatly reduce the modification effect. Therefore, improving compatibility become an important direction for modifications [17].

Polyurethanes (PUs) are the special materials coupled with rigid and flexible segments, containing carbamate (−NHCOO−) repeating units in the polymer main chains [18,19], which would exhibit great mechanical properties, low gentleness and simple processing. To date, the soft sections mainly include polyether or polyester. These chains with rich heteroatoms are proved to dissolve alkali metal salts and effectively conduct lithium ions. While the hard sections with the abundant hydrogen bond structures provide physical crosslinking points, which significantly improve the mechanical stability of electrolytes. Several soft segments of PU-based polymer electrolytes (PEs) have previously been studied [20,21]. For instance, polyether PU-based PEs, polycarbonate PU-based PEs, single-ion PU-based PEs, and self-healing PU-based PEs. Besides, the free volume of polymer chains declined with the increase of hard segment concentration. The reduced chains mobility seriously affected the ionic conductivity. Therefore, removing this barrier should be necessary to promote the further applications of PU-based PEs.

The unique structure of PUs prompted their compatibility with different polymers, so blending technology could demonstrate the suitability in preparation of novel CPEs for LIBs applications. Luo et al. [22] synthesized an ionic liquid type waterborne polyurethane (IWPU), which was hybridized and LiClO4 as CPE without no organic solvents. The novel green CPE with 20% LiClO4 exhibited a higher conductivity (1.8 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 80 °C). There is no denying that the ionic conductivity was failure to meet application conditions. To further improve the electrochemical properties, Bao et al. [23] introduced TPU to PEO for CPE, which presented a high ionic conductivity of 5.3 × 10−4 S cm−1 with the electrochemical stability above 5 V (vs. Li+/Li) at 60 °C. The LiFePO4 (LFP)/Li assembled with this CPE showed an attractive discharge capacity and outstanding cycling stability. Recently, a UV photocurable polyurethane acrylate (PUA) resin has been blended with 30 wt% lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) to reach a maximum ionic conductivity of 0.09 mS cm−1 at 100 °C. Li/C-LFP half-cell assembled with PUA electrolyte reached a battery discharge capacity value of 139 mAh g−1 at C/30 rate. The photocurable SPE is a possible solution for LIBs applications [24].

Due to the special ladder type main chain structure, contorted or kinked centers prevent packing space efficiently. The polymers of intrinsic microporosity (PIMs) possess unusually high free volume and high internal surface area [25–27]. PIM-1, as one of the most well-known PIMs family, has been widely studied for gas separation [28] and liquid adsorption [29,30]. The unique rigid microporous structure offers superior mechanical properties. In recent years, PIMs have had more applications in the field of energy storage systems [31,32], such as SEI layer [33], a separator in fuel cell [34,35] or lithium-sulfur batteries [36,37].

In this work, we designed the rigid skeleton of PIM-1 as the hard segments, PEG as the soft segments and 4,4′-Diphenylmethane diisocyanate (MDI) as the binder based on the structural characteristics of PUs. A novel PPU polymer was obtained for the first time. Subsequently, it was doped into PEO polymer matrix, aiming to improve the mechanical and electrochemical properties of PEO-based polymer electrolytes. The synthesized PPU/PEO integrated superior mechanical strength and efficient conduction of Li+, leading the formation of a promising electrolyte for high-performance and high-safety LIBs.

5, 5′, 6, 6′-Tetrahydroxy-3, 3, 3′, 3′-tetramethyl-1, 1′-spirobisindane (98%, Alfa Aesar) and tetrafluoroterephthalonitrile (98%, Aldrich) were purified as reported [38]. Polyethylene glycol (PEG, average molecular weight 2000, HEOWNS), 4,4′-Diphenylmethane diisocyanate (MDI, 98%, Meryer), poly (ethylene oxide) (PEO, average molecular weight 500000, BASF) and LiTFSI (99.9%, HEOWNS) were dried at a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 24 h. Anhydrous potassium carbonate (99%, Fisher), LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 (NCM523, 98%, Candlelight New Energy Technology), LFP (98%, Candlelight New Energy Technology) and carbon black (super P, Candlelight New Energy Technology) were dried in a vacuum oven at 110 °C overnight. Lithium foil (Candlelight New Energy Technology) was stored in the argon-filled glove box as received. Anhydrous N, N-Dimethylformamide (DMF, Aladdin), n-Hexane (AR grade, Aladdin), Acetonitrile (CH3CN, AR grade, Aladdin) and N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP, AR grade, Aladdin) were used as received without further purification.

Firstly, PIM-1 and amidoxime−PIM-1 (AOPIM-1) were synthesized according to the methods described previously [38]. PPU was prepared in the anhydrous and oxygen-free environment [39]. All reagents and solvents need to dry before reaction. AOPIM-1and PEG were dried in a vacuum oven at 110 °C for 24 h. MDI was removed water at 60 °C in the same way. In a 100 mL three neck round bottom flask assembled with a spiral condenser, (0.27 g, 0.5 mmol) AOPIM-1 powder was dissolved in 60 mL anhydrous DMF and heated up to 90 °C under the inert N2 environment. Subsequently, (0.5 g, 2 mmol) MDI and (4.1 g, 2 mmol) PEG were added to the solution, which was stirred for 72 h. When the reaction finished, DMF was removed by distillation under reduced pressure. The residual solid was stirred in the n-Hexane overnight, then filtered. The product was dried to obtain a pale-yellow PPU powder in a vacuum oven at ambient temperature for 24 h. Yield 4.72 g: 95.4%.

The CPEs were prepared using a solution casting technique. For all CPEs samples, the molar ratio of Li+/EO was kept at 1:13. The different weight percentages of 5, 15, and 25% of PPU powder was dissolved in dry DMF to form a homogenized solution. Simultaneously, PEO and LiTFSI were dissolved in dry ACN. Two above solutions were mixed and stirred to obtain the final casting solution, which was poured into a polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) dish and dried in an oven at 60 °C. The residual solvent was removed in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 24 h. Besides, the standard PEO/LiTFSI SPE was also prepared by the same method for comparison. All electrolyte films were cut into disks with diameters of 17 mm and stored in the argon-filled glove box.

The LFP cathode was prepared by mixing LFP (80%) cathode active material, PEO (10%) and super P (10%) in NMP. Similarly, the NCM523 cathode was prepared by mixing NCM523 (80%) cathode active material, polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF, 10%) and super P (10%) in NMP. The obtained slurry was cast onto aluminum foil and dried completely in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 24 h. Then, the obtained electrodes were cut into disks with diameters of 15 mm. Eventually, the prepared cathode sheets possessed the active material mass loading on each current collector ranges from 4.0 to 4.8 mg cm−2. Two cathode sheets were adopted for LFP/electrolytes/Li or NCM523/electrolytes/Li cell assembling.

1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra of PIM-1, AOPIM-1 and PPU were recorded using a Bruker Avance II 400 MHz instrument. Polymer solutions for NMR were prepared in CDCl3 or DMSO‑d 6. Signal peaks for the solvents were used as references.
The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was carried out using a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS5 FTIR spectrometer with the ATR accessory to distinguish the structures of AOPIM-1 and PPU.

The surface morphologies of CPEs were measured with a field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Hitachi S4800). X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Bruker) was used to study the crystal structure of PPU powder and CPEs in the 2θ range from 10° to 60° at room temperature.

The thermal stability of CPEs was measured by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). About 5 mg of CPEs material was subjected to the thermogravimetric analyzer for temperature scanning from the ambient temperature to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The glass transition temperature (Tg) and melting temperature (Tm) of CPEs were determined by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). The samples were scanned from −50 to 80 °C to detect endothermic change. The heating rate was 10 °C min−1. The crystallinity percentage (χc) of polymer was calculated via Eq. (1):
(1)
χ c
= Δ H /
(
ƒ PEO
× Δ H
PEO
)
× 100 %
where ΔH was the measured melting enthalpy of polymer, ƒPEO was the weight fraction of PEO, and ΔHPEO was the melting enthalpy of completely crystalline PEO (213.7 J g−1) [40].

The surface mechanical property of electrolytes was tested by a nano-indentation instrument (NanoTest Vantage) with a constant pressure of 1 mN and the tensile strength was measured by using a Universal Testing Machine (Instron 5966) with a tensile speed of 10 mm min−1. Each electrolyte was cut into a standard specimen with the size of 1.5 × 7.5 cm2.

The CR2032 coin cells were assembled with two stainless steels (SS) blocking electrodes sandwiched the electrolytes. The ionic conductivities (σ) of electrolytes were calculated by Eq. (2):
(2)
σ = l / R S
where l was the thickness (cm) of electrolyte, S represented the interface area (cm2) between electrolyte and electrodes, R was the bulk resistance of electrolyte. It was obtained by testing electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) with an Autolab PGSTAT 302 N under the open-circuit voltage in the frequency range of 10−1 Hz to 106 Hz. The activation energy was calculated based on
(3)
σ = A
exp
(
− Ea / k T
)
where the σ was the ionic conductivity, A was the pre-exponential factor, Ea was the activation energy for lithium-ion migration, k was the Boltzmann constant while T was the measured temperature (K).

To explore the electrochemical stability of the electrolyte, the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was tested using a Li/electrolyte/SS cell with a voltage range from 3.0 V to 6.0 V at a scanning rate of 1 mV s−1 at 50 °C. The lithium ions transference number (t Li +) was calculated using Eq. (4):
(4)
t
Li
+
=
I s
/
I o
(
Δ V −
I o
R o
)
/
(
Δ V −
I s
R s
)

For a Li/Li cell, the polarization chronoamperometry was measured for the initial current I
o and the steady-state current I
s by a polarization voltage (ΔV) of 10 mV during 3600 s. Before and after the polarization measurement, EIS was conducted to detect the initial interfacial resistances R
o and the final interfacial resistances R
s .

To determine the interfacial stability of electrolytes and Li electrode, Li symmetric cells were assembled for testing the galvanostatic cycling performance at a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2. To detect the cycling charge/discharge performance, LFP/electrolyte/Li or NCM523/electrolyte/Li cell was operated in the potential range from 2.5 to 3.8 V or 2.7–4.3 V with a multichannel battery testing system (LAND CT2001A), respectively.

Fig. 1 a shows the synthetic procedure of PPU. A novel polyurethane polymer PPU was firstly synthesized by a two-step reaction. In the first step, AOPIM-1 was prepared by a rapid reaction of nitrile groups with hydroxyl amine under reflux conditions. Subsequently, four equivalents molar of PEG were connected to two equivalent molars of the hydroxyl and amine groups with isonitrile groups as intermediate.

The structures of the synthesized PIM-1 and AOPIM-1 are confirmed by 1H NMR results (Fig. S1), while the structure of PPU is also characterized as shown in Fig. 1b. The characteristic peaks of hydrogens on the PIM skeleton appear at δ = 6.83 ppm (g), 6.48 ppm (f), 2.0 ppm (b) and 1.24 ppm (a). Besides, the peaks of hydrogens on amines mainly appear at δ = 9.64 ppm (l), 8.53 ppm (k) and 8.23 ppm (j), which provide the evidence of polycondensation reaction. The characteristic peaks, corresponding to the hydrogens on the benzene rings of the isocyanate segments, appear at δ = 7.35 ppm (i) and 7.09 ppm (h). Methylene−CH2−supraproton peaks on isocyanate appear at δ = 3.63 ppm (c). The characteristic peaks of ether segment –CH2CH2O− are mainly found at δ = 4.17 ppm (e) and 3.79 ppm (d). The above results could provide the adequate evidence of AOPIM-1 polyurethaneization.

AOPIM-1 and PPU were analyzed based on FTIR measurements (Fig. 1c). As shown in Fig. 1c, the characteristic peaks of amidoxime groups in AOPIM-1 appear at 3482 and 3397 cm−1, respectively. The N–H bond stretching vibration is assigned to 3323 cm−1 from urethane bands of PPU. The peak at 2955 cm−1 is assigned to the antisymmetric stretching vibration of methyl, and the peak at 2863 cm−1 is assigned to the stretching vibration of C–H bond in AOPIM-1 and PPU. Compared with AOPIM-1, the stronger absorption peak for PPU appear at 2917 cm−1, assigning to the antisymmetric stretching vibration of –CH2 in the polymer sample. Furthermore, other important characteristic vibration peaks for CN and CO are between 1784 and 1566 cm−1. There are the characteristic bands of C–N–H at 1542 and 1509 cm−1, which could be assigned to the bending vibration of secondary amides groups in PPU. The sharp peaks at 1110 and 1107 cm−1 are assigned to C–O–C and C–N stretching vibrations. Besides, the vibrational absorption peak of C–H bond appears at 801 cm−1 while these of N–H bond are located at 805 and 765 cm−1.

Fig. 2 a depicts the fabrication of CPEs by the solution casting procedure. The prepared CPEs are labeled as CPE-X% PPU (x = 5%, 15%, 25%). The prepared flexible and freestanding films will be used as the electrolytes in LIBs.

The crystalline degree of electrolyte films could be verified by XRD spectra (Fig. 2b). Since PEG possesses the same –CH2CH2O− fragment as PEO, PPU appears the identical characteristic diffraction peaks around at 19° and 23° corresponding to the semicrystalline structure of PEO. When PPU is blended with SPE, the diffraction peak intensities should be weaker, indicating the incorporation of PPU in PEO-based electrolytes can increase the amorphous regions of PEO. The stronger chain motility of PPU over SPE is further demonstrated. This may be attributed to the coordination of Li+ with N–H and CO on the PPU molecules. The hydrogen bonds are disrupted between polar functional groups of PPU and PEO. Thereby, it is believed the facilitated transport of lithium ions in the solid electrolytes.

Lithium-ion conductivity is a prime parameter for electrolytes. The Arrhenius plots were recorded for the ionic conductivities of electrolytes from 30 to 50 °C (Fig. 2c). To examine the lithium-ion transport energy-barrier in electrolyte membranes, Ea was also calculated. Obviously, the ionic conductivity is greatly influenced by the content of PPU. When 15% PPU is blended with SPE, the conductivity reaches its maximal, i.e. 4.34 × 10−5 S cm−1 at 30 °C or 1.82 × 10−3 S cm−1 at 50 °C, while it is only 4.70 × 10−6 or 3.27 × 10−4 S cm−1 for SPE. When 25% PPU is incorporated into PEO electrolyte, the conductivity takes on a downward trend. This is derived from that the overdosed polymer plasticizer with low intrinsic conductivity may undergo aggregation, which would reduce the free volume of PEO and disrupt the continuity of Li+ transfer nanochannels in the electrolyte. This may be responsible for the nonmonotonic phenomenon of ionic conductivity. Moreover, the calculated Ea is 0.75 eV for SPE. While the calculated activation energies are 0.64, 0.61 and 0.67 eV for CPE-5%, 15% and 25% PPU, evidencing the lowest barrier of Li+ transport for CPE-15% PPU. Fig. 2d displays the impedance spectra of CPE-15% PPU film as a function of temperature, indicating that there is an inverse correlation of EIS impedance with temperature. The hard segments of PPU are conducive to the concentration increase of lithium-ion, where polar groups would promote the dissolution of lithium salt in the electrolyte. While the soft segments of PPU are conducive to increasing the migration rate of carriers, which is mainly attributed to the reduced crystalline degree of PEO polymer matrix. Therefore, the CPE-15% PPU is chosen as the model CPE in the following study.

The surface morphologies of electrolyte membranes were further characterized by SEM measurements. As shown in Fig. 2e and f, a flat surface of non-doped SPE is observed, while the surface of CPE-15% PPU exhibits slightly wrinkled because the presence of PPU fillers destroys the resetting of PEO chains. The thickness of CPE-15% PPU membrane is around 166 μm, while that of pristine PEO electrolyte is ca. 172 μm. Fig. 2g shows the uniform distribution of N in CPE-15% PPU film. The uniform distribution of element N from PPU further confirms the homogeneous blending of PPU and PEO polymer, which would decrease the interfacial resistance due to firmly adhering with electrode. As shown in Fig. S2, the surface morphology becomes rough and uneven after PPU content is increased, being attributed to the obvious agglomeration of excessive PPU. The transport of lithium ions between electrolytes and electrodes will be severely affected since the interfacial resistance is increased.

The thermal properties of the electrolytes were characterized using DSC and TGA under N2 atmosphere. In Fig. 3 a, CPE-15% PPU possesses a lower Tg (−41.56 °C) than that of SPE (−41.14 °C). Compared with pristine SPE, the Tm of CPE-15% PPU declines by 8.92 °C. The reduced Tm and Tg further indicate the lower crystallinity for CPE-15% PPU. Accordingly, the crystallinity degree of 5.9% for CPE-15% PPU is evaluated by the change of melting enthalpy, lower than that of SPE (24.6%) (Table S1). The increased amorphization degree for Li+ ions mobility is mainly ascribed to that the plasticizing effect of PPU could alter the regularity of PEO chains.

The mechanical properties of electrolytes should be an important factor to inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites. The nanoindentation measurements were performed, and demonstrated in Fig. 3b. Compared with SPE, CPE-15% PPU has a much shallower displacement under the same pressing force, which ought to be attributed to the excellent mechanical properties of PPU hard segments, the high hard skeleton of PIM-1, and the strong hydrogen bonding interactions between polar functional groups (N–H and CO) and PEO matrix. Ultimately, CPE-15% PPU with superior mechanical strength tends to restrain the growth of lithium dendrites.

The strain–stress curves of electrolyte films were measured (Fig. 3c). The tensile strength of the original unmodified SPE film shows a mechanical stress of 0.46 MPa with an elongation-at-break value of 421%, while CPE-15% PPU membrane can be stretched to 750% with a tensile breaking strength of 4.1 MPa due to the strong toughness of PPU. These results imply that the reinforced flexibility would improve the external force tolerance of composite electrolytes by PPU incorporation.

TGA experiments were conducted to check thermal decomposition behaviors of electrolytes. As shown in Fig. S3, the decomposition of two electrolytes occurs at 380 °C, and almost completes at 460 °C. This means the addition of PPU does not lower the excellent thermal stability of pristine SPE.

To investigate whether CPEs membranes could be applied in the high-voltage battery systems, the LSV curves of SPE and CPE-15% PPU were measured. The decomposition potential of CPE-15% PPU happens at ∼5.3 V versus Li+/Li, higher than ∼4.1 V for pristine SPE (Fig. 3d). This result indicates that the as-obtained CPE-15% PPU makes it suitable for high-voltage cathode materials. Lithium-ion transference number (t Li +) should be another major factor for SSEs. Fig. 3e and f exhibits the i-t curves and the AC impedance spectra of symmetric Li/Li cells at 50 °C. The calculated t Li + of CPE-15% PPU is 0.68, 4.53 times than that of SPE (0.15).

Fig. 4 demonstrates the lithium-ion transport pathways with schematic transportation mechanism diagram in CPE-15% PPU. In SPE, the transport of Li+ is mainly through complexation and decomplexation of ether oxygen groups. A large number of crystalline regions hinder the transport of Li+, resulting in the low ionic conductivity of SPE. For comparison, the crystalline regions of PEO are reduced because the existence of N–H and O–H groups in PPU with strong hydrogen bonding with PEO segments. This could provide a continuous Li+ transport pathway along PEO chains with the PEG segments of PPU. In addition, the action of Li+ with polar CO and C–O binding sites on PIM and MDI frameworks promotes the dissociation of lithium ions from lithium salts, providing another new lithium-ion transport pathway. More carriers and larger Li+ transference number would spur a lower overvoltage, leading to the enhanced electrochemical stabilities and energy densities of lithium-ion batteries.

To further understand the PPU positive effect on Li+ transport in electrolytes, FTIR data are employed to analyze the interactions among PEO, LiTFSI, and electrolytes. Compared with pure SPE, the stronger peak at ∼3470 cm−1 corresponding to O–H stretching band for CPE-15% PPU should be attributed to the formation of hydrogen bonds between PEO matrix and PPU polymer plasticizer (Fig. S4) [41,42]. As shown in Fig. 4b, the characteristic peaks at 1324.4 and 1307.2 cm−1 correspond to the asymmetric –SO2 stretching of TFSI− anion. They are observed at 1354.6 and 1335.3 cm−1 for pristine PEO electrolyte, shifting to 1355.7.8 and 1342.1 cm−1 in the composite electrolyte with PPU. In addition, the peaks for symmetric –CF3 groups stretching at 1244.3 cm−1 relates to TFSI− anion, shifting to 1225.7 cm−1 for electrolytes. While two peaks for asymmetric –CF3 groups stretching at1201.3, 1142.7 cm−1 shift to 1191.5, 1175.9 cm−1, respectively. Synchronously, the stretching vibration of N–S groups for LiTFSI at 1062.6 cm−1 shifts to 1085.1 cm−1 for electrolytes. The peaks at 774.4, and 746.6 cm−1 attribute to the symmetric and asymmetric S–N–S stretching for TFSI− anion, shifting to 760.6 and 739.2 cm−1 for electrolytes. Obviously, weaker peak intensities are observed for CPE-15% PPU compared with SPE. The shifts and changes for the characteristic peaks confirm that the strong interaction between PPU and TFSI−, which should be responsible for the enhanced dissociation of LiTFSI for releasing more Li+ [43].

After PPU imported in PEO matrix, the enhanced vibration intensities at 1059.4 and 961.1 cm−1 corresponding to the stretching vibrations of C–O–C units are induced by the strong Lewis acid centers of PPU. Moreover, the vibration of –CH2 at 1359.8 cm−1 in blank PEO polymer shifts to 1354.5 cm−1, which is obviously reinforced owing to the strong vibrations of C–O–C groups. These results reveal that the strong interaction between PPU and PEO chains could create new high-conductivity pathways for improvement of Li+ ion migration.

In order to explore the interfacial stability between electrolyte and lithium metal anode, the symmetrical Li/Li batteries with SPE and CPE-15 % PPU were assembled, and galvanostatic Li striping/plating cycling measurements were performed at a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 and capacity of 0.025 mAh cm−2 under 50 °C. Fig. 5 a−c displays the cell assembled with SPE exhibits a detectable failure after only 230 h and a sharply decline of the high voltage profile (50 mV), which is ascribed to the short circuit due to the growth of lithium dendrites. In sharp contrast, the battery containing CPE-15 % PPU possesses a lower voltage profile (less than 50 mV). Remarkably, a higher stable cycling operation exceeds 2000 h, which is mainly ascribed to the outstanding electrochemical stability of PPU polymer filler. The surface of Li anode based on SPE exhibits a large number of irregular lithium dendrites (Fig. 5d and e), whereas the growth of lithium dendrites is effectively inhibited by a stable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer from uniform deposition of Li+ (Fig. 5f). The Li anode from Li/CPE-15% PPU/Li cell displays a relatively flat surface (Fig. 5g). The hard segments of PPU tremendously enhances the mechanical strength of CPE. Besides, the higher lithium-ion transference number boosts the rate performances and long-term cycling stabilities of the cells by reducing electrode polarization during lithium-ion deposition.

The rate performances of LFP/Li cells assembled with SPE or CPE-15% PPU were compared at 50 °C. As shown in Fig. 6 a, it shows no difference at low rates, but the cell with CPE-15% PPU has considerably higher discharge capacities than those of the cell with SPE, when the rate increases from 1.0 to 3.0 C (1 C = 170 mA h g−1) in every five-cycle sequence. Noteworthily, the capacities could be completely recovered thoroughly with the rate recovering to 0.2 C. As indicated in Fig. 6b, the charge/discharge curves of LFP/CPE-15% PPU/Li delivers 153, 144, 122, 78 and 41 mAh g−1, corresponding to 0.2 C, 0.5 C, 1.0 C, 2.0 C and 3.0 C, respectively. Obviously, this novel composite electrolyte with PPU has the distinguished electrochemical stabilities due to high ionic conductivity and Li+ transference number.

All-solid-state LFP/SPE and CPE-15% PPU/Li batteries have been applied to detect the electrochemical cycling performances at 0.5 C at 50 °C (Fig. 6c). The battery with CPE-15% PPU achieves a high initial discharge capacity of 149.4 mAh g−1 with 84.3% capacity retention. The capacity could remain at 125.9 mAh g−1 after 890 cycles with a coulombic efficiency fluctuating around 99%. While the battery using SPE shows an unstable cycling performance (of only 85 cycles). The low Li+ transfer number results in the severe electrode polarization, which promotes the rapid growth of lithium dendrites to pierce the electrolyte separator. Fig. 6d reveals that the cell assembled with CPE-15% PPU possesses a stable polarization voltage, which further demonstrates the excellent electrochemical stability and high discharge capacity of CPE-15% PPU. Moreover, as manifested in Fig. 6e and f, the assembled LiFePO4/CPE-15% PPU/Li battery still demonstrates the excellent electrochemical cycling performances at 1C. The specific capacity of the CPE-15% PPU film still remains 116.2 mAh g−1 with a significant capacity retention of 82.4% after 500 cycles, while SPE suffers from the short circuit after 47 cycles. Attributed to the stable interface compatibility and the construction of long-distance continuous lithium-ion migration channels, CPE-15% PPU fully demonstrates a high energy density. In addition, Table S2 shows the comparison of CPE-15% PPU with recently reported PEO-based composite electrolytes on long-term electrochemical cycling performances of LFP/Li cells [44–51].

Furthermore, in quest of high voltage suitability, NCM523/CPE-15% PPU/Li cells were assembled and checked at 0.5 C with a high voltage range (2.7–4.3 V). As shown in Fig. 6g and h, the NCM523/Li cell assembled with CPE-15% PPU has a high discharge capacity of 135.4 mAh g−1 with a capacity retention of 86.8% after 240 cycles. The CPE-15% PPU has the superior electrochemical stability in the long-term operation under high-voltage atmosphere That should have a great application potential in rechargeable Li batteries.

In summary, we designed and synthesized a novel polyurethane polymer of intrinsic microporosity (PPU) by combining toughness with softness, and further applied it to fabricate PEO-based electrolyte. The as-synthesized electrolytes possessed the superior compatibility and high mechanical strength, leading to the formation of high safety and energy-density Li-ion batteries. Moreover, the favorable electrochemical properties were achieved with the ionic conductivity of 1.82 × 10−3 S cm−1 at 50 °C with a wide voltage stability window of 5.3 V (vs Li+/Li) and the Li+ transference number of 0.68. The excellent mechanical stability from the hard segments of PPU suppressed the growth of lithium dendrites. The symmetrical Li/Li cell could be stably cycled up to 2000 h at a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 (50 °C). When coupled with LiFePO4 cathode, the solid-state battery with CPE-15% PPU delivered the prominent cycling performances of 84.3% capacity retention after 890 cycles at 0.5 C and 82.4% capacity retention after 500 cycles at 1.0 C (50 °C). Besides, the synthesized CPE could also achieve a high specific discharge capacity of 135.4 mAh g−1 after 240 cycles at 0.5 C under high-voltage atmosphere. The research in this study could represent a significant advance in design of composite polymer electrolytes for high-performance all-solid-state lithium-ion batteries.

Xiaoyan Hu: Writing – original draft, Visualization, Validation, Software, Methodology, Investigation, Formal analysis, Data curation. Baoquan Zhang: Writing – review & editing, Supervision, Resources, Project administration, Funding acquisition, Conceptualization.
